title-group.article-title: Association of RPS20 Loss-of-Function Variants With Colorectal Cancer Risk in a Cohort of Over 950,000 Individuals

author-notes.corresp: Jennifer Herrera-Mullar, MGC, DMA; e-mail: jherreramullar@ambrygen.com.

permissions.copyright-statement: © 2025 by American Society of Clinical Oncology

license.license-p: Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial No Derivatives 4.0 License: https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-nd/4.0/

sec.title: PURPOSE
sec.p: RPS20 is a proposed colorectal cancer (CRC) predisposition gene, with only four families with putative loss-of-function (pLoF) variants published. The prevalence, phenotypic spectrum, and clinical management recommendations for RPS20 heterozygotes remain unknown.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: Retrospective review of approximately 950,000 individuals undergoing multigene panel testing (MGPT) for cancer predisposition identified 36 individuals with pLoF variants in RPS20. Clinical features, tumor prevalence, and age at onset were compared with Lynch syndrome (LS) and wild-type (WT) cohorts.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: Thirty-six individuals (0.004%) had 28 unique pLoF variants in RPS20 and a total of 42 primary tumors, 78.6% of which were CRC with a median age of diagnosis of 50 years. A total of 16.7% of individuals had multiple CRC primaries, and a majority (71.4%) were mismatch repair–proficient (pMMR). Signet ring cell (SRC) pathology was significantly enriched compared with WT (P = <.0001). The odds ratio for CRC was significantly higher than that for the MLH1-related LS cohort (odds ratio [OR], 45.3 [95% CI, 21.3 to 101] and OR, 16.9 [95% CI, 14.9 to 19.2], respectively).

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: RPS20 is associated with early-onset, pMMR CRC enriched for SRC pathology. Comparison of prevalence showed a statistically significant two-fold increase in the odds of developing CRC compared with an MLH1 LS cohort. These data confirm the gene-disease relationship between RPS20 and CRC and support clinical management guidelines similar to MLH1-related LS.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Current genes associated with adult-onset hereditary colorectal cancer (CRC) explain <20% of familial CRC.1 Despite more comprehensive sequencing technologies, few new genes associated with hereditary CRC have been uncovered. In 2014, Nieminen, et al proposed RPS20 (NM_001023.3) as a novel gene associated with highly penetrant, early-onset CRC.2 However, including this initial report, only six families with variants in RPS20 have been described.3-6 Four of these families harbor truncating variants,2,4-6 and two families harbor missense variants with an unknown functional impact.3,5 Because of the rarity of published cases, this gene-disease relationship (GDR) has remained uncharacterized with limited gene-disease validity (GDV), such that no variants can be classified above a variant of uncertain significance (VUS) per American College of Medical Genetics7 and ClinGen guidelines.8 Furthermore, currently published cases are from highly ascertained, small cohorts selected for suspicion of hereditary CRC, and these results have not been replicated or validated in larger, diverse cohorts. The actual prevalence of RPS20-related cancer predisposition remains unknown, as well as comprehensive phenotypic characterization (including specific tumor characteristics) or lifetime tumor risk estimates to guide clinical management recommendations for individuals with variants in RPS20. Additional data validating the role of RPS20 in CRC or other cancer predisposition are crucial to inform genetic testing and guide individual patient management. Here, we present a series of 36 individuals with putative loss-of-function variants (pLoF, defined as truncating variants expected to undergo nonsense-mediated decay) in RPS20 from a cohort of nearly one million individuals undergoing multigene panel testing (MGPT) for diverse cancer phenotypes. We provide the prevalence of RPS20 pLoF alterations in a cancer cohort, a comprehensive phenotypic analysis of these individuals, and a comparison of the prevalence of various features between a Lynch syndrome (LS) and wild-type (WT) cohort. This analysis formally characterizes the GDR between RPS20 and high-penetrance, early-onset CRC while also providing vital data to inform the clinical management of individuals with RPS20 pLoF alterations.

list-item.p: Are RPS20 loss-of-function variants a definitive cause of high-penetrance, early-onset colorectal cancer (CRC)?

The odds of CRC in the RPS20 cohort were over 45 times higher compared with a similarly ascertained pan-cancer multigene panel testing cohort with negative results and more than twice as high as those in individuals with MLH1-related Lynch syndrome (LS). The RPS20 cohort showed a significant association with both multiple primary CRCs and signet ring CRC (P < .001).

Our data confirm the association of RPS20 with early-onset CRC predisposition, allowing for classification of variants as likely pathogenic or pathogenic, and indicate that the CRC risks are similar to or higher than those related to MLH1-related LS, providing important information for clinical management.

sec.title: Curated Datasets
sec.p: For comprehensive phenotypic characterization of the RPS20 cohort, approximately 950,000 hereditary cancer (HC) MGPT were retrospectively reviewed. MGPT ranged from 17 genes to 91 reportable genes, and all cases had RPS20 coverage as part of the library. The cohort contained individuals with confirmed heterozygous pLoF in RPS20 between March 2017 and July 2024 (n = 36). Three individuals had RPS20 ordered as a reportable finding, and in the remaining 33 cases, RPS20 was not included in the gene list ordered. RPS20 splicing variants were confirmed to result in premature termination via capture RNA-seq.9 Clinical data and demographic information were obtained by requisition form or additional clinical documentation provided to this laboratory. Information regarding tumor burden, tumor type, tumor characteristics, gastrointestinal polyp history, age(s) of diagnosis, and family cancer and polyp history was recorded. Clinical features of the RPS20 cohort were compared with those of a similarly ascertained, comprehensively curated cohort of 19,810 individuals with negative HC MGPT (76 genes; referred to as WT-curated).

sec.title: ICD10 Datasets
sec.p: International Classification of Diseases codes (ICD)10 datasets were built from a consecutive cohort of MGPT-tested patients ordering a germline-only test from January 2019 through April 2024. These datasets allowed for CRC prevalence comparison between the RPS20 cohort and a large cohort of individuals with LS, serving as a positive control dataset. The use of ICD10 codes corresponding to CRC was validated against a large, manually curated data set, revealing a sensitivity of 86.3% and a specificity of 99.8% for CRC and a mean difference between age at onset and age at testing of 1.98 years (data not shown). Age at onset was not available in this dataset; therefore, age at testing was used in analyses. Codes corresponding to a CRC diagnosis are provided in Appendix 1 .

Within this ICD10 cohort, 384,445 individuals with comprehensive HC testing (37-85 genes) were identified who had no VUS or (likely) pathogenic (LP/P) variants and comprised the WT-ICD10 dataset. In addition, within this ICD10 cohort, a total of 11,437 patients with LS were identified: MLH1 LP/P (n = 1,077), MSH2 LP/P (n = 2,610), MSH6 LP/P (n = 3,650), or PMS2 LP/P (n = 4,100).

Finally, 513 additional individuals with confirmed heterozygous missense variants in RPS20 were identified in this ICD10 cohort to determine CRC prevalence. Missense variants with a filtering allele frequency of ≥0.00735% were excluded because they were above the maximum credible frequency for a disease-causing variant in RPS20.10,11 Missense variants were assessed in aggregate and stratified based on their predicted deleteriousness using BayesDel,12 an in silico metapredictor of variant effect, for comparisons with ICD10-WT (Appendix Table A2).

sec.title: Statistical Methods
sec.p: Demographics and clinical characteristics of the comprehensively curated RPS20 cohort were compared with those of the WT-curated cohort using Fisher's exact test, and age at testing, first cancer, and first CRC diagnosis were tested using the Wilcoxson rank-sum test (Table 1). The prevalence of CRC among the ICD10 data sets for RPS20 pLoF and LS probands was plotted and compared with that of the WT-ICD10 using Fisher's exact test (Fig 1, Appendix Table A2). The Kaplan-Meier time-to-event plot was created using the ICD10 datasets, and cases were censored for CRC diagnosis and age at testing, which was used as a proxy for age at onset of CRC. Data were plotted and analyzed by the log-rank test using SRPlot.13,14

caption.p: RPS20 Cohort Characteristics and Cancer Associations Versus Wild-Type

fn.p: Abbreviations: CRC, colorectal cancer; NA, not applicable or unable to be calculated; OR, odds ratio; pLoF, putative loss-of-function; WT, wild-type.
One individual had two primary CRCs that both had signet ring CRC so although four individuals had this, there are five tumors described with signet ring pathology.

caption.p: RPS20 pLoF heterozygotes are characterized by early-onset and multiple primary CRC exceeding that of MLH1 heterozygotes. (A) Swimmer plot showing individual proband characteristics (P1-P36) until age at genetic testing. Deidentified proband number, the identified RPS20 heterozygous variant identified and the MMR status, if applicable, is included in the arrow. Proband sex at birth is indicated by color, with pink as female and blue as male. Recurrent variants are colored with green text. Cancer diagnoses are denoted by unique shapes per the key, and multiple diagnosis, when applicable, are indicated with a number within the relevant cancer shape. The presence and number of colonic polyps and first-degree relatives diagnosed with CRC are indicated at the far right with the number of polyps or relatives included in parentheses. Cases are grouped by variant type which is indicated at the far left; (B) forest plot comparing the prevalence of CRC in individuals with pLoF in RPS20 and LP/P in LS genes MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, and PMS2 compared with a similarly ascertained WT cohort of individuals with no VUS/LP/P identified via pan-cancer MGPT (up to 85 genes). All LS genes (used as positive control cohorts) show a significantly higher prevalence of CRC compared with WT. Individuals with pLoF in RPS20 also show a significantly higher prevalence of CRC compared with WT and at least 2-fold higher than MLH1 (OR of 45.3 v 19.3). (C) Kaplan-Meier time-to-event plot censoring at CRC diagnosis at age at testing among heterozygotes for MLH1, MSH2, MSH6, PMS2, and RPS20. Affectation status was derived from ICD10 codes (Appendix 1, Appendix Table A1). 95% CI are shaded. aIndividual P7 is also heterozygous for an ATM pathogenic variant, a gene with limited evidence for CRC predisposition. bIndicates that the tumor is positive for MLH1 promoter hypermethylation. CRC, colorectal cancer; dMMR, deficient MMR; FDR, first-degree relative; LP, likely pathogenic; LS, Lynch syndrome; MGPT, multigene panel testing; MMR, mismatch repair; N, no; NOS, not otherwise specified; NP, not provided; P, pathogenic; pLoF, putative loss-of-function; pMMR, proficient MMR; VUS, variant of uncertain significance; WT, wildtype; Y, yes.

sec.title: Gene-Disease Validity Assessment
sec.p: GDV analysis was completed using an evidence-based scoring framework,15 with current scoring methods detailed in Appendix Tables A1 and A3.

sec.title: Ethics Approval and Consent to Participate
sec.p: The WCG Institutional Review Board determined the study to be exempt from the Office for Human Research Protections Regulations for the Protection of Human Subjects (45 CFR 46) under category 4. Retrospective data analysis of deidentified data exempted the study from the requirement to receive consent from patients.

sec.title: RPS20 pLoF Cohort Characteristics
sec.p: A total of 36 of 950,000 individuals had one of 28 unique pLoF variants in RPS20, representing an overall frequency of 0.004%. Among the identified variants are three different start-loss variants (individuals P1-P3), 18 nonsense or frameshift variants causing premature termination (individuals P4 through P24), and seven canonical splicing variants (individuals P25 through P36; Fig 1A). Notably, several variants were recurrent in this cohort: two individuals were heterozygous for each RPS20 c.10A>T (P.K4*), RPS20 c.122delG (p.R41Kfs*10), RPS20 c.298C>T (p.Q100*), and RPS20 c.104-1G>A. Three individuals were heterozygous for each RPS20 c.3+1G>A and RPS20 c.104-2A>G. Canonical splicing variants were predicted to lead to premature termination after review of RNA capture-seq (data not shown). One individual was also heterozygous for another PV in ATM (Fig 1A, individual P7).

Within the RPS20 cohort, a majority self-identified as female at birth (61.1%), which is statistically fewer compared with the WT-curated cohort (83.8%, Table 1). The self-reported ethnic characteristics were similar between the RPS20 and WT-curated cohorts. Although the age at testing and age at first CRC diagnosis were similar between them, there was a statistically younger median age at first cancer within the RPS20 cohort compared with the WT-curated cohort (RPS20 48 years v WT-curated 53 years, P = .020). There was also a statistically higher prevalence of having more than one primary cancer diagnosis in the RPS20 cohort (RPS20 = 25% v WT-curated = 10.97%, P = <.001). Consistent with observational findings from previous studies, individuals in the RPS20 cohort reported polyps, and the frequency of this was statistically higher than that of the WT-curated cohort (RPS20 = 25% v WT-curated = 13%, P = .044). A total of 8 of 9 (88.9%) individuals reported a total polyp count of <10. One individual (P16) reported 50-100 polyps. A total of 5 of 9 individuals reported pathology, all of which were adenomatous polyps.

Three clinical features stand out as dramatically more frequent in the RPS20 cohort relative to the WT-curated cohort: The prevalence of CRC in the RPS20 cohort was 63.9%, whereas the prevalence in the WT-curated cohort was only 4.59% (P = <.001). In addition, 19.44% of individuals in the RPS20 cohort reported multiple primary CRCs versus 0.40% of the WT-curated cohort (P < .001). Five individuals (13.9%) reported two primary CRCs, whereas one individual (2.8%) reported three primary CRCs (Fig 1, individuals P3, P6, P24, P31, and P35 and individual P27, respectively).

Among the 23 (63.9%) individuals in the RPS20 cohort who reported CRC, 14 also submitted tumor testing information for mismatch repair deficiency/mismatch repair proficiency (pMMR) for LS. The majority of these individuals had pMMR CRCs. Three individuals (2.1%) had abnormal immunohistochemistry (IHC) with absent MLH1/PMS2 (one of which was confirmed to have MLH1 promoter hypermethylation), and one individual reported abnormal IHC but with no details (Fig 1). Finally, four individuals (11.1%) in the RPS20 cohort reported signet ring cell (SRC) pathology for their CRCs, whereas only 0.06% of the WT-curated cohort did (P < .001). Of note, one individual had two CRCs with SRC pathology for a total of five tumors (Table 1).

Other cancer diagnoses included 22.7% (5 of 22) with female breast cancer, which was not statistically different from the WT-curated cohort (38.56%, P = .187). Of the 42 reported cancers, there was one report each for anal, appendiceal, bladder, and basal cell carcinoma (2.4% each). When compared with the frequency in the WT-curated cohort, only the anal cancer was statistically significant (RPS20 = 2.8% v WT-curated = 0.06%, P = .022).

sec.title: Comparison of RPS20 pLoF With LS Cohorts
sec.p: The observation of a highly statistically significant frequency of CRC relative to the WT-curated cohort warrants benchmarking to other CRC predisposition genes that have clinical management guidelines. Thus, the RPS20 pLoF cohort was compared with a similarly ascertained LS cohort from this laboratory. To maximize the number of individuals and to reduce bias that may be built into selective curation of cases and changes in ascertainment bias over time, a cohort of consecutive cases with limited available information was built. Information documented included sex at birth, ICD10 codes corresponding to CRC, and age at testing (Appendix 1). A total of 33 of 36 individuals with RPS20 pLoF were identified in this ICD10 data set. Three individuals from the curated data set were absent because of date- and/or test-inclusion differences. In addition, two individuals noted to have CRC did not have corresponding ICD10 codes for CRC, which is within the rate of error based on sensitivity analysis for the ICD10 data set (Methods).

Odds ratios (ORs) were calculated relative to the WT-ICD10 cohort of individuals without reported VUS/LP/P variants. The ICD10-RPS20 pLoF and ICD10-Lynch cohorts all had significantly higher odds of CRC compared with WT-ICD10 and reflected the current understanding of the magnitude of CRC penetrance among the LS genes (RPS20: OR = 45.3 > MLH1: OR = 16.9 > MSH2: OR = 11.5 > MSH6: OR = 4.6 > PMS2: OR = 3.7). Critically, the ICD10-RPS20 cohort had statistically significantly higher odds of CRC than the ICD10-MLH1 cohort and the upper bound 95% confidence interval for ICD10-MLH1 did not overlap with the lower bound for ICD10-RPS20 (Fig 1B, Appendix Table A2). By contrast, the ICD10-RPS20 missense cohort did not have statistically significant odds of CRC compared with the WT-ICD10 cohort. Stratification of missense variants with BayesDel score 0.41-0.493 revealed the highest enrichment of CRC compared with ICD10-WT (OR, 1.85 [95% CI, 0.81 to 4.24]; P value .14) but was still not statistically significant. No missense variants had a BayesDel score higher than 0.493 (Appendix Table A2).

In evaluating the age at testing among the ICD10-RPS20 and ICD10-Lynch cohorts using Kaplan-Meier analyses censored for CRC (per ICD10 code), as a group, individuals with RPS20 pLoF alterations were censored more frequently and at earlier ages than individuals with LS, suggesting an earlier age at onset for the RPS20 pLoF cohort; individuals with LS, again, reflected the current understanding with respect to the magnitude of penetrance and age at onset for the different genes, with MLH1-related LS having the highest risk and earliest age at onset and PMS2-related LS having the lowest incidence and age at onset of CRC (Fig 1C).

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: Identification of genes involved in hereditary CRC is an important ongoing effort as less than a quarter of familial cases are explained by genetic causes.1 A proportion of this missing heritability may be explained by non-Mendelian genetics or nongenetic factors.1,16 Alternatively, additional Mendelian causes may exist but have not yet been uncovered for various reasons.17 The discovery of RPS20's putative association with hereditary CRC was latent in this modern era of cancer genetic testing, which is surprising given the very high crude penetrance revealed in this study. This is likely attributable to the high level of constraint against LoF in this gene, with very few individuals harboring pLoF in the literature (four families),2,4,5 large general population databases such as gnomAD (pLI = 0.97, observed/expected = 0.15 (0.06-0.48)),18 and in clinical cohorts such as described herein (frequency of 0.004%), where the frequency is 100-fold rarer than MLH1-associated LS (0.11%). Until now, the reinforcement of the association between RPS20 and CRC and the evaluation of additional associated features, including risk, have been impossible.

To our knowledge, this is the largest reported series of individuals with pLoF in RPS20 and represents a 9-fold increased contribution to currently published pLoF cases in the literature, allowing for comprehensive characterization and quantification of RPS20-related cancer predisposition. While previous publications have suggested an association with hereditary CRC, data are from very few cases and from cohorts ascertained for hereditary CRC, which can bias results and artificially inflate penetrance. This study uses a genotype-first approach in a diverse clinical MGPT cancer cohort referred for multiple tumor indications and provides a more accurate crude penetrance for CRC. The results show that even in a cohort not specifically ascertained for hereditary CRC, the odds of being diagnosed with CRC in individuals heterozygous for pLoF in RPS20 are dramatically higher than that in a similarly ascertained WT cohort (OR, 45.3-fold).

In total, with the patients in this study plus those from the literature, there are 54 individuals from 40 families with pLoF in RPS20 (Appendix Table A4). Of note, two additional literature-based familial CRC cases harbored missense variants in RPS20 (detailed in Appendix Table A2) with an unknown functional impact and were excluded from these pLoF totals.3,5 The missense variant analyses in this study showed no significantly increased odds of CRC (OR, 0.95 [95% CI, 0.55 to 1.51]; P = .91), further supporting a mechanism of disease as loss of function predominantly because of truncations subject to nonsense-mediated decay. Additional studies are warranted to elucidate the pathogenicity of identified missense variants in clinically suspicious families. Although the published studies look at prevalence and age at onset among members of three pLoF families, it is important to note that CRC prevalence was higher and age at onset was younger in this study of unrelated individuals relative to the published literature. This further reinforces these initial findings and represents a major step forward in solidifying the GDV between RPS20 and early-onset CRC. Combining these genotype-first cohort results with the previously published families elevated the GDV score from limited to moderate for RPS20-related CRC predisposition, allowing for the classification of variants as LP/P. Additional case reports and/or cosegregation analyses would result in a definitive GDV classification.

This large cohort allows, for the first time, the statistical comparison of individuals with RPS20 pLoF with control cohorts. Both the RPS20 and WT-curated cohorts had similar ethnic distributions, and although each had a majority of female probands, the RPS20 cohort showed a significantly higher proportion of males. This is likely due to referral bias within this clinical cohort, where early-onset female breast cancer is the most frequent primary indication for MGPT. Overall, compared with WT, the RPS20 cohort was statistically enriched for cancer diagnoses of any type (83.33% RPS20 v 53.82% WT) with earlier age at first cancer diagnosis (48 years RPS20 v 53 years WT). These individuals also more commonly had multiple primary cancer diagnoses (25.00% RPS20 v 10.97% WT) and more commonly had polyps (25.00% RPS20 v 13.00% WT). Finally, the RPS20 cohort was dramatically enriched for CRC (63.9% RPS20 v 4.59% WT), multiple primary CRCs (19.44% RPS20 v 0.40% WT), and CRC with SRC pathology, a rare subtype of CRC that encompasses only 1%-2% of all CRC diagnoses19 (11.11% RPS20 v 0.06% WT). In addition, based on observational data, CRC was overwhelmingly pMMR. This finding is consistent with previous reports and emphasizes the distinction of RPS20-related CRC from LS-related CRC.

Although 25% (9 of 36) of our probands reported polyps, which was statistically higher than our WT-curated cohort (P = .044), 88.9% (8 of 9) had fewer than 10 polyps, supporting that RPS20 confers risk for nonpolyposis CRC. Reported polyps had adenomatous pathology; no previous pathology related to polyps has been published.2 Proband P16 (reporting 50-100 cumulative polyps) was subjected to additional analyses (sensitive bioinformatics pipeline review of NGS and RNA analyses) to rule out mosaic or deep intronic findings in polyposis genes, with no additional variants detected. However, we cannot exclude another etiology for this proband's polyposis.

Extracolonic cancers in the RPS20 cohort were rare; however, the presence of anal cancer (a rare cancer type) was enriched compared with WT (2.8% RPS20 v 0.06% WT). Given that this was a single case, further studies are necessary to demonstrate associations with anal cancer and the other extracolonic cancers that were observed. Notably, the observation of RPS20 pLoF variants in very few people without CRC underscores the high crude penetrance for this GDR. The significance of SRC CRC is also a novel finding not previously reported in association with RPS20.2-5

A limitation of this study is the lack of available tumor sequencing data in individuals with germline pLoF variants in RPS20. Future studies in this area could shed light on whether biallelic loss of RPS20 or other mutational features are seen in RPS20 heterozygotes. In addition, data regarding colonoscopy and pathology results for many probands were not available and therefore do not allow us to draw strong conclusions on the polyp phenotype in this population.

The identification of high penetrance supports implementing clinical management for individuals with RPS20 pLoF variants. To support the level of management that may be needed, a comparison with MLH1-associated LS was drawn. There is two-fold increased odds for CRC in individuals with RPS20 pLoF over individuals with MLH1-associated LS, and notably, the upper and lower 95% confidence intervals do not overlap (OR, 45.3 RPS20-ICD10 v OR, 16.9 WT-ICD10, Fig 1B, Appendix Table A2). This finding supports RPS20 as a more penetrant CRC predisposition gene relative to MLH1-related LS. While the relative enrichment of CRC in RPS20 and MLH1 should be replicated in additional cohorts, the increase shown in RPS20 demonstrates that CRC management should at least mirror that of MLH1-related LS.20

In conclusion, RPS20 is associated with an early-onset, highly penetrant, MMR-proficient CRC predisposition caused by heterozygous pLoF. Multiple primary CRCs and SRC pathology are likely part of the spectrum but should be replicated in other cohorts. Because the prevalence and age at onset of CRC in RPS20 pLoF heterozygotes are similar to or worse than those of MLH1 heterozygotes, these data support implementation of management guidelines similar to those for MLH1-related CRC. Testing of RPS20 is warranted in individuals with a significant personal and/or family history of early-onset CRC, especially if MMR proficient and/or with SRC pathology. Finally, because of this study, the GDV for RPS20-related CRC predisposition can now be considered at least moderate, and variants are eligible to be classified as LP/P, paving the way for appropriate clinical management as proposed.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
ack.p: We would like to thank Cynthia Martinez, BS, and Lily Hoang, BA, for their contributions to data acquisition for this case series, and Brooklynn Gasser, for her analysis for age at testing versus age at diagnosis for the ICD10 cohort.

sec.title: DATA SHARING STATEMENT
sec.p: Ambry Genetics supports open data sharing. Data that are not included in this published article will be made available upon request except detailed patient data that would compromise HIPAA-compliant safeguards applied to protect patient privacy. Internal GDV scores are submitted to the Gene Curation Coalition Database (GenCC DB; https://thegencc.org/), and variant classifications are submitted to ClinVar (https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/clinvar/).

fn.p: Abbreviations: GDV, gene-disease validity; WT, wildtype.

caption.p: Prevalence of CRC (obtained from ICD10 data) in All Cohorts With Comparison With the Wild-Type Cohort

fn.p: NOTE. The prevalence of CRC in each cohort: MLH1-positive, MSH2-positive, MSH6-positive, PMS2-positive, and RPS20 pLOF heterozygotes was compared with a WT group of individuals with no VUS/LP/P using Fisher's exact test.

Abbreviations: CRC, colorectal cancer; ICD, International Classification of Diseases codes; LP/P, likely pathogenic or pathogenic variant; MGPT, multigene panel testing; OR, odds ratio; pLoF, putative loss-of-function; VUS, variant of uncertain significance; WT, wild-type.
Two in-frame insertion-deletions resulting in a missense change do not have a BayesDel score.

tr.td: Case-control data (must have lower 95% CI > 1.5 for positive points and a OR < 1.2 OR and lower bound CI of <0.5 for negative points)
Phenotype of positives in study matches the propose gene disease relationship
Methodology of variant detection should be with equivalent analytical performance between cases and controls
Matched cases and controls for demographics
Matched cased and controls for ancestry
Equivalently evaluated cases and controls for the phenotype and family history

Case-level dataNoncommon variant, no other evidence 0.1 pt; AR: half pts per variant; for GDR with assumed or demonstrated low penetrance, pLoF 2pts are not applicable. Use the non-pLoF row to assign appropriate weight
Segregating >2 and <7 meioses in family OR LOD ≥0.9 and <2.1
Segregating >6 meioses in family OR LOD ≥2.1
Internally calculated genome-wide significant (P < 1 × 10-6) excess of de novos in large cohort exome study can count as 1 patient
AR disease with extensive pedigree, LOD score >3 (at least 4 affected in 8 meiosis)
In vitro experiments show the same disease pathology after similar genetic modification
Determination of mechanism consistent with patient-reported alterations: WT transfection rescues mutation-expressing cells OR dosage experiments show dominant negative or gain-of-function mechanism
Gene function similar to the pathology of human disease
Phenotype and genotype match human disease
Same truncating/frameshift alteration is identified in appropriate tumors
Missense alterations in the gene identified in appropriate tumor AND reported in at least 3 patient tumors AND functionally validated
Gene is frequently mutated in appropriate tumor (larger data sets)

fn.p: Abbreviations: GDR, gene-disease relationship; GDV, gene-disease validity; LOD,logarithm of the odds; MOD, mechanism of disease; OR, odds ratio; pLoF, putative loss-of-function; WT, wild-type.
Use caution characterizing GDR as moderate or higher for common cancer types without at least one supportive case-control study/analysis.
Must have Genetic Evidence points to assign any points (if experimental evidence only = No evidence).
